R. 3, 14</bibl></cit>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Rarely neque ... et = non quidem ... sed: amicitias neque facile admisit et constantissime retinuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:66" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 66</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n16278.13" n="K" level="1"> Less freq., tum ... et, et ... tum, in the same sense: <cit><quote lang="la">omnis ejus oratio tum in virtute laudanda et in hominibus ad virtutis studium cohortandis consumebatur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 1, 4, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et in ceteris eloquentiae partibus, tum maxime in celeritate et continuatione verborum adhaerescens, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:93:320" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 93, 320</bibl></cit>. See Hand Turs. II. pp. 467-540.</sense></entryFree>
eta: <entryFree id="n16279" type="main" key="e_ta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ēta</orth>, <gen>n.</gen>, indecl., <sense id="n16279.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the seventh letter of the Greek alphabet</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1518,001:Litt. 43" default="NO"><author>Ter. Maur.</author> Litt. 43</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Idyll. 12, 12, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
etenim: <entryFree id="n16280" type="main" key="e^te^nim"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĕt-ĕnim</orth>, <sense id="n16280.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">conj.</hi>, subjoins a corroborative clause, or one which contains the reason of a preceding statement, <hi rend="ital">for</hi>, <hi rend="ital">truly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and indeed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">because that</hi>, <hi rend="ital">since</hi> (not freq. till class. times, esp. in Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">verum profecto hoc petere me precario a vobis jussit ... Etenim ille, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. prol. 26</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:6:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 2, 6, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:9:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 5, 9, 44</bibl>: praeclare quidem dicis; <cit><quote lang="la">etenim video jam, quo pergat oratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:3:32" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 3, 32</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> de Sen. 5 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">quippe etenim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 104</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:547" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 547</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:800" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 800</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">5, 1062 al.: tutus bos etenim rura perambulat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:5:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 5, 17</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n16280.1" n="II" level="1"> Esp., introducing parenthetical clauses (cf. enim, II. A.): <cit><quote lang="la">ejus autem legationis princeps est Hejus (etenim est primus civitatis), ne forte, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:10:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 10, 17 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:17:62" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 17, 62</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 31, 99</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 24 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl> (etenim always begins the clause, Krebs, Antibarb. p. 423; Madvig, Opusc. Acad. 1, 390). See Hand, Turs. II. pp. 540-545.</sense></entryFree>
eteocles: <entryFree id="n16281" type="main" key="E^te^o_cle_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ĕtĕōclēs</orth>, <itype>is and ĕos</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)eteoklh=s</foreign>, <sense id="n16281.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">son of Oedipus and Jocasta</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brother of Polynices;</hi> he was the cause of the Theban war, described by the Roman poet Statius in the Thebais, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:21:82" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 21, 82</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 76" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 76</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> Eteoclis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:3:214" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 3, 214</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Eteocleos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 421</bibl></cit>; <case>acc.</case> Eteoclea, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 688</bibl>.— Hence, </sense><sense id="n16281.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ĕtĕōclēus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of Eteocles</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">contentiones,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 10, p. 245, 30</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
etereius: <entryFree id="n16282" type="main" key="Eterei^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Eterëĭus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n16282.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a freedman of the Roman knight Corellius</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:122" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 17, 26, § 122</bibl>. —Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Eterëĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of Etereius</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nux,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 23, 25, § 94</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:122" default="NO" valid="yes">17, 17, 26, § 122</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
etesiacus: <entryFree id="n16283" type="greek" key="e^te_si^a^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĕtēsĭăcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">e)thsiako/s</foreign>, <sense id="n16283.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of the trade-winds</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 3, 4, § 36</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
etesiae: <entryFree id="n16284" type="greek" key="e^te_si^ae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĕtēsĭae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">e)thsi/ai</foreign> (sc. <foreign lang="greek">a)/nemoi</foreign>), <sense id="n16284.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the winds that blow annually during the dog-days for forty days</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Etesian winds</hi>, <hi rend="ital">trade-winds</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 5:10 sq" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 5, 10 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:2:56" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 11, 2, 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:58" default="NO">58</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:716" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 716</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:53" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 53</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 2, 15 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; id. poët. Or. 45; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 107</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 23</bibl> et saep.—In <number>sing.</number>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ete-sias</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">o( e)thsi/as</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:335" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 34, 77, § 335</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
etesius: <entryFree id="n16285" type="main" key="e^te_sius"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĕtēsius</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">e)th/sios</foreign>, <sense id="n16285.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">yearly.</hi> </sense><sense id="n16285.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop.: <cit><quote lang="la">flabra aquilonum = etesiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:742" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 742</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:730" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 730</bibl> Munro ad loc.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:715" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 715</bibl> sqq.—</sense><sense id="n16285.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">lapis,</quote> <trans><tr>a kind of stone</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:157" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 22, 43, § 157</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ethecae: <entryFree id="n16286" type="main" key="ethe^cae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ethĕcae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">e)kqe/tai</foreign>, <sense id="n16286.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a gallery</hi> or <hi rend="ital">portico</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,053:41:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Ezech. 41, 15</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ethice: <entryFree id="n16287" type="greek" key="e_thi^ce_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ēthĭcē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">h)qikh/</foreign>, <sense id="n16287.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">moral philosophy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ethics</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:21:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 21, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:2:15" default="NO">12, 2, 15</bibl>; also <orth extent="full" lang="la">ēthĭca</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 3, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ethicus: <entryFree id="n16288" type="greek" key="e_thi^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ēthĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, (scanned ĕthĭcīs, <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Hamart. 583</bibl>), <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">h)qiko/s</foreign>, <sense id="n16288.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">moral</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ethic</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">res,</quote> <trans><tr>ethics</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:2:4" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dictio,</quote> <trans><tr>which shows the character</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 8, 11</bibl></cit>.— Hence <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ēthĭcos</orth> = <foreign lang="greek">h)qikw=s</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">morally</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Contr. 2:12:8" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Contr. 2, 12, 8</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ethnicalis: <entryFree id="n16289" type="main" key="ethni^ca_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ethnĭcālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n16289.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">heathenish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pagan</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">litterae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Spect. 5</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ethnice: <entryFree id="n16290" type="main" key="ethni^ce_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ethnĭcē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, <sense id="n16290.0" n="I" level="1"><xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">the foll.</ref></xr> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
ethnicus: <entryFree id="n16291" type="greek" key="ethni^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ethnĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">e)qniko/s</foreign>, <sense id="n16291.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">heathenish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pagan;</hi> and <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ethni-cus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a heathen</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Pud. 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:5:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 5, 47</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">18, 17</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ethnĭce</orth>, <hi rend="ital">heathenishly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vivere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Pud. 9</bibl></cit>. <pb n="662" /> <cb n="ETIA" /></sense></entryFree>
ethologia: <entryFree id="n16292" type="greek" key="e_tho^lo^gi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ēthŏlŏgĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">h)qologi/a</foreign>, <sense id="n16292.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the art of depicting</hi> or <hi rend="ital">imitating character</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:9:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 9, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 95:66" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 95, 66</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Gramm. 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ethologus: <entryFree id="n16293" type="greek" key="e_tho^lo^gus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ēthŏlŏgus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">h)qolo/gos</foreign>, <sense id="n16293.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who jestingly imitates the manners</hi>, <hi rend="ital">actions</hi>, <hi rend="ital">gestures</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">of others</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a mimic</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:59:242" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 59, 242</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 60, 244</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ethopoeia: <entryFree id="n16294" type="greek" key="e_tho^poei^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ēthŏpoeĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">h)qopoii/+a</foreign>, rhet. t. t., <sense id="n16294.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an expression of character</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0425,001:de Fig. 1:21, p. 66 al" default="NO"><author>Rutil. Lup.</author> de Fig. 1, 21, p. 66 al.</bibl>; cf. the foll. art., II.</sense></entryFree>
ethos: <entryFree id="n16295" type="greek" key="e_thos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ēthos</orth>, <itype>ĕos</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">h)=qos</foreign>. * <sense id="n16295.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Manners</hi>, <hi rend="ital">morals</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Carm. 15, 101</bibl>.—* </sense><sense id="n16295.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A depicting of character.</hi>—In <hi rend="ital">acc. plur.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ethē,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 10, 36, § 98</bibl></cit>; in <hi rend="ital">abl. plur.</hi>: in ethesin Terentius poscit palmam, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 374, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
etiam: <entryFree id="n16296" type="main" key="e^ti^am"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĕtĭam</orth>, <sense id="n16296.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">conj.</hi> [cf. Gr. <foreign lang="greek">e)/ti</foreign>; with ending -am, as in quoniam, nunciam, etc.; cf. Brix ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:prol. 3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. prol. 3</bibl>], annexes a fact or thought to that which has already been said, <hi rend="ital">and also</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and furthermore</hi>, <hi rend="ital">also</hi>, <hi rend="ital">likewise</hi>, <hi rend="ital">besides</hi> (syn. quoque). </sense><sense id="n16296.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc etiam ad malum accersebatur malum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 3, 3, 22</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:3:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 3, 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Sen. 6, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:52:130" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 52, 130</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tute istic (dixisti) etiam astante hoc Sosia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:2:115" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 2, 2, 115</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed etiam est, paucis vos quod monitos voluerim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:prol. 53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. prol. 53</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:6:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 3, 6, 17</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 12, 38</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">atque alias etiam dicendi quasi virtutes sequetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:chapter=40" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 40 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">unum etiam vos oro, ut, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>one thing more</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:8:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 8, 54</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:1:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 5, 1, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 5, 5, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:352" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 352</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:24 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 24 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiamne hoc negabis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:2:128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 2, 2, 128</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:3:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 2, 3, 40</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi quidem etiam Appii Caeci carmen ... Pythagoreorum videtur. Multa etiam sunt in nostris institutis ducta ab illis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:2:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 2, 4</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:58" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 58</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hei mihi! Etiam de sorte nunc venio in dubium miser? ... Etiam insuper defrudet?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:2:2:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 2, 2, 38</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:10" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 10 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">caret epulis exstructisque mensis et frequentibus poculis: caret ergo etiam vinolentia et cruditate et insomniis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Sen. 13, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiam tu quoque assentaris huic?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:2:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 2, 2, 70</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">etiam quoque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:4:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 2, 4, 95</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:1:120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 1, 120</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 3, 118</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:292" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 292</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:517 al" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 517 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:1:3" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:18:12:9" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 18, 12, 9</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quoque etiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. prol. 30</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2, 85</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">121</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:4:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 4, 2, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:1:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 4, 1, 28</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 1, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 88 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">v. quoque.— Esp. freq. in the connection: non modo (or solum) ... sed (or verum) etiam: tenebat non modo auctoritatem, sed etiam imperium in suos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Sen. 11, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inveteratas non solum familiaritates exstingui solere, sed odia etiam gigni sempiterna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:chapter=10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 10 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque solum ut quieto, sed etiam ut magno animo simus hortantur, neque auxilium modo defensioni meae, verum etiam silentium pollicentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit> Conversely: <cit><quote lang="la">tantum ... non etiam: si vultum tantum, non etiam animum accommodavimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:2:26" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 2, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">periculum tantum, non etiam offensa vitatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:2:67" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 9, 2, 67</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:4:35 al" default="NO">7, 4, 35 al.</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quasi vero oratio rhetorum solum, non etiam philosophorum sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:6:17" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 6, 17</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n16296.2" n="II" level="1"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n16296.3" n="A" level="2"> To annex a more important idea, <hi rend="ital">and even</hi>, <hi rend="ital">nay</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae omnes docti atque sapientes summa, quidam etiam sola bona esse dixerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:13:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Deiot. 13, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nos enim defendimus, etiam insipientem multa comprehendere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 47, 144</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si infantes pueri, mutae etiam bestiae paene loquuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:21" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 1, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quis mortalium tolerare potest, illis divitias superare, nobis rem familiarem etiam ad necessaria deesse?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 20:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 20, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illiteratum, iners ac paene etiam turpe est non putare, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:2:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 2, 3, 8</bibl></cit> et saep.—Freq. after negative sentences, for immo, potius, <hi rend="ital">nay</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rather</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even</hi>: Mamertina civitas improba antea non erat; <cit><quote lang="la">etiam erat inimica improborum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:11:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 11, 31</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc idem nostri saepius non tulissent, quod Graeci laudare etiam solent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:45:153" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 45, 153</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid, si ne dives quidem? quid, si pauper etiam?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:6:1:42" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Par. 6, 1, 42</bibl></cit> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">tantum abesse dicebat, ut id consentaneum esset, ut maxime etiam repugnaret,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 9, 28</bibl></cit>; cf. Lentul. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:15:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 12, 15, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:17" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 17</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 20</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">immo etiam, hoc qui occultari facilius credas, dabo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:4:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 5, 4, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quin etiam insuper vestem omnem miserae discidit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 4, 3, 4</bibl></cit>; v. immo and quin.—Freq. with comparatives <cb n="ETIA" /> for the sake of intensity, <hi rend="ital">yet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">still</hi> (in later Lat. replaced by adhuc): <hi rend="ital">He.</hi> Mane, nondum audisti, Demea, Quod est gravissimum. <hi rend="ital">De.</hi> An quid est etiam amplius? <hi rend="ital">He.</hi> Vero amplius, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:4:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 4, 22</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut enim in corporibus magnae dissimilitudines sunt: sic in animis exsistunt majores etiam varietates,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:30:107" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 30, 107</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sunt autem etiam clariora vel plane perspicua,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 5, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dic, dic etiam clarius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 75 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plusculum etiam quam concedet veritas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:12:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 5, 12, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:36" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 4, 36</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Athos mons est adeo elatus, ut credatur altius etiam quam unde imbres cadunt surgere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:2:10" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 2, 10</bibl></cit>.—Rarely with a <hi rend="ital">comp.</hi> in contrast with its own <hi rend="ital">posit.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui magno in aere alieno majores etiam possessiones habent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:8:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 8, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:1:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 1, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:7:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 4, 7, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad Alesiam magna inopia, multo etiam major ad Avaricum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:47:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 47, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n16296.4" n="B" level="2"> With the demonstrative notion of the <hi rend="ital">jam</hi> predominating, used as an affirmative, <hi rend="ital">certainly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">granted</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by all means</hi>, <hi rend="ital">yes indeed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">yes</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut sequens probabilitatem, ubicumque haec aut occurrat aut deficiat, aut etiam, aut non respondere possit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 32, 104</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 30, 97</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:25:70" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 25, 70</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Com. 3, 9</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Jupp.</hi> Numquid vis? <hi rend="ital">Al.</hi> Etiam; <cit><quote lang="la">ut actutum advenias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:3:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 3, 46</bibl></cit>: <hi rend="ital">Th.</hi> Numquid processit ad forum hodie novi? <hi rend="ital">Si.</hi> Etiam. <hi rend="ital">Th.</hi> Quid tandem? <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:4:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 4, 3, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 5, 3, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">misericordia commotus ne sis. Etiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:31:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 31, 65</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:2:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 2, 3, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Zeno in una virtute positam beatam vitam putat. Quid Antiochus? Etiam, inquit, beatam, sed non beatissimam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 43, 134</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:chapter=26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Planc. 26 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid? etiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 4, 5</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 13, 6</bibl>; 2, 6 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:1:7:section=24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 1, 7, § 24</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">An.</hi> Num quid patri subolet? <hi rend="ital">Ge.</hi> Nihil etiam, <hi rend="ital">nothing at all</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:1:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 3, 1, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil etiam audio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 5, 5, 13</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n16296.5" n="C" level="2"> With the idea of time predominating, <hi rend="ital">yet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as yet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even yet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">still</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even now</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">etsi admodum In ambiguo est etiam, nunc quid de hac re fuat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:193" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 193</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 4, 3, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">olim fano consumebatur omne quod profanum erat, ut etiam fit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=54" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 54</bibl></cit> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">cum iste etiam cubaret, in cubiculum introductus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">invalidus etiamque tremens, etiam inscius aevi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:189" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 189</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:485" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 6, 485</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 61:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 61, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed tu etiamne astas?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:2:2:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 2, 2, 89</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:2:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 2, 55</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:4:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 3, 4, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:4:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 4, 4, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quousque tandem abutere, Catilina, patientia nostra? quamdiu etiam furor iste tuus nos eludet?</quote> <trans><tr>how much longer?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 1</bibl></cit>.—With negatives: <cit><quote lang="la">quia tibi minas viginti pro amica etiam non dedit,</quote> <trans><tr>not yet</tr>, <tr>never yet</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:3:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 3, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non satis pernosti me etiam, qualis sim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 2, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non dico fortasse etiam quod sentio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:6:12" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 6, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec plane etiam abisse ex conspectu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:43:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 43, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">improbum facinus, sed fortasse adhuc in nullo etiam vindicatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 84</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil suspicans etiam mali,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hunc ego numquam videram etiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:8:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 5, 8, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 9, 62</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid egerint inter se, nondum etiam scio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:1:2:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 1, 2, 117</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 1, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:3:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 3, 3, 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:2:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 1, 2, 30</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec ego omnia, vixdum etiam coetu vestro dimisso, comperi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n16296.6" n="D" level="2"> In familiar lang., in interrogations, esp. when made indignantly, like our <hi rend="ital">what? pray?</hi> etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">etiam caves, ne videat forte hinc te a patre aliquis exiens?</quote> <trans><tr>are you on your guard</tr>, <tr>pray?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiam tu, here, istinc amoves abs te?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:3:124" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 3, 3, 124</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiam clamas, carnufex?</quote> <trans><tr>what? do you bawl?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:220" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 220</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 225</bibl>; 2, 1, 21; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:2:1:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 2, 1, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:7:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 7, 16</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 21 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl> al.: is mihi etiam gloriabitur se omnes magistratus sine repulsa assecutum? <hi rend="ital">what? and will he boast to me?</hi> etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 1, 2</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 59</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2, 42</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n16296.7" n="E" level="2"> In familiar lang., with imperatives, <hi rend="ital">again</hi>, <hi rend="ital">once more: Tr.</hi> Circumspice dum, numquis est, Sermonem nostrum qui aucupet. <hi rend="ital">Th.</hi> Tutum probe est. <hi rend="ital">Tr.</hi> Circumspice etiam, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:2:2:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 2, 2, 43</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 2, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiam tu, homo nihili, quod di dant boni, cave culpa tua amissis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:2:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 5, 2, 70</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 2, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 5, 4, 1</bibl>.—In impatient questions: <cit><quote lang="la">scelerate, etiam respicis?</quote> <trans><tr>are you going to look round?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:2:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 2, 4, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiam vigilas?</quote> <trans><tr>at once</tr>, <tr>immediately</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 2, 1</bibl></cit>, <cb n="ETIA" /> 35: <cit><quote lang="la">etiam aperis?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 2, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiam tu taces?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:113" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 113</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 2, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiam tu hinc abis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 3, 3, 9</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">etiamne abis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 3, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiamne ambulas?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:1:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 1, 1, 95</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n16296.8" n="F" level="1"> Etiam atque etiam denotes that an action is done uninterruptedly, incessantly; whence it also conveys the idea of intensity, <hi rend="ital">constantly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">perpetually; repeatedly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">again and again</hi>, <hi rend="ital">over and over; pressingly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">urgently</hi>: temo superat cogens sublime etiam atque etiam noctis iter, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=73" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 73</bibl> Müll. (Trag. v. 246 ed. Vahlen): <cit><quote lang="la">etiam atque etiam argumenta cum argumentis comparare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 4</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 16, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">optimus quisque confitetur, multa se ignorare et multa sibi etiam atque etiam esse discenda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:28:69" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 3, 28, 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 13, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">commonefacere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 13, 72</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">affirmare promissa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">curare, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:41:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 41, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">consulere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 38, 9</bibl></cit>: se avertere, Balb. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 15</bibl>, A, 2: <cit><quote lang="la">queri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:63:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 63, 61</bibl></cit> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">te moneo, hoc etiam atque etiam ut reputes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:3:2:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 3, 2, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cogitare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 1, 1, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">considerare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Imp. Pomp. 19 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 45 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl> Drak.: <cit><quote lang="la">reputare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 85:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 85, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">videre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,004:chapter=12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Div. in Caecil. 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 19, 62</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 36, 28</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aspicere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 18, 76</bibl></cit> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc te vehementer etiam atque etiam rogo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 5</bibl></cit>, <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; 13, 28 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 72</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec quamquam nihilo meliora sunt, nunc etiam atque etiam multo desperatiora,</quote> <trans><tr>constantly more desperate from day to day</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 6, 22</bibl></cit> (B. and K. read nunc atque): <cit><quote lang="la">quare etiam atque etiam sunt venti corpora caeca,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>most positively</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:295" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 295</bibl></cit>. Vid. Hand Turs. II. pp. 545-578.</sense></entryFree>
etiamdum: <entryFree id="n16297" type="main" key="e^ti^amdum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĕtĭamdum</orth> (also written separately), <sense id="n16297.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">hitherto</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even till now</hi>, <hi rend="ital">still</hi>, <hi rend="ital">yet</hi> (rare; usually after a negative; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">etiamtum, etiamnum): dissimulabo, hos quasi non videam neque esse hic etiamdum sciam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil etiamdum harpagavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 4, 2, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:1:2:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 1, 2, 72</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:5:3:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 5, 3, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque etiamdum scit pater,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:1:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 1, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum poteris igitur (veni), quoniam etiamdum abes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:31:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 31, 1</bibl></cit> (cf. Hand Turs. II. p. 322 sq.; Krebs, Antibarb. p. 425 sq.).</sense></entryFree>
etiamnum: <entryFree id="n16298" type="main" key="e^ti^amnum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĕtĭam-num</orth> <itype>and</itype> (more freq., always in Cic. and Caes.) <orth extent="full" lang="la">ĕtĭam-nunc</orth> (also written separately, etiam num ... nunc), <sense id="n16298.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">conj.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">yet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">till now</hi>, <hi rend="ital">still</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even now</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even to this time</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even at this time.</hi> </sense><sense id="n16298.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen. (in all periods): <hi rend="ital">Ev.</hi> Etiamnunc mulier intu'st? <hi rend="ital">Sy.</hi> Etiam, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:4:5:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 4, 5, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:2:3" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 2, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:5:4:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 5, 4, 16</bibl>; Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 11, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Contr. 4:26" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Contr. 4, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">de materia loquor orationis etiamnunc, non ipso de genere dicendi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:34:119" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 34, 119</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut mihi permirum videatur quemquam exstare, qui etiamnunc credat, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:47" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 47 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vos cunctamini etiamnunc, quid intra moenia deprehensis hostibus faciatis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 52:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 52, 25</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 31:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> J. 31, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 38</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:28:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 28, 78</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:7:454" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 7, 454</bibl> et saep.—With negations: <cit><quote lang="la">neque quicquam cum ea facit etiamnum stupri,</quote> <trans><tr>not as yet</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:prol. 99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. prol. 99</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 12 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec Telamoniades etiam nunc hiscere quicquam Audet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:231" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 231</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo de homine nihil etiamnunc dicere nobis est necesse,</quote> <trans><tr>nothing further</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:59:163" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 59, 163</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n16298.2" n="B" level="2"> In respect to past time, i. q. etiam tum, <hi rend="ital">till that time</hi>, <hi rend="ital">till then</hi>, <hi rend="ital">still</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Athenis in Lyceo cum etiamnum platanus novella esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:37:5" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 37, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:10:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 10, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">dixisti, paululum tibi esse etiamnunc morae, quod ego viverem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:4:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 1, 4, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nullo etiamnunc usu rei militaris percepto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:40:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 40, 6</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 62, 6</bibl>: cum Balbus etiamnunc in provincia esset, Pollio ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 32 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">cum tristis hiems etiamnum frigore saxa Rumperet, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:135" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 135</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:155" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 3, 155</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 3, 5, § 16</bibl> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n16298.3" n="II" level="1"> Sometimes for etiam (post-Aug.), <hi rend="ital">also</hi>, <hi rend="ital">besides</hi>, <hi rend="ital">moreover</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">his addemus etiamnum unam Graecae inventionis sententiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:211" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 33, 39, § 211</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 32, 5, 18, § 49</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">alia etiamnum generibus ipsis in sexu differentia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 16, 10, 19, § 47</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:133" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 22, 25, 64, § 133</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:26:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 5, 26, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:7:29" default="NO" valid="yes">7, 29</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">duas etiamnunc formulas praepositis adiciam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:5:3:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 5, 3, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in quibus etiamnunc hodie, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 8, 47, § 85</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 113" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 113</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">si plus est, quod tolli opus est, adhibenda sunt etiamnum vehementiora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:26:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 5, 26, 30</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so with comparatives (cf. etiam, II. A.),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 5, 28</bibl></cit>, <pb n="663" /> <cb n="ETSI" /> 17; 8, 20; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:177" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 22, 35, § 177</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 87" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 87</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:102 al" default="NO">102 al.</bibl> Vid. Hand Turs. II. pp. 580-587.</sense></entryFree>
etiamsi: <entryFree id="n16299" type="main" key="e^ti^amsi"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĕtĭam-si</orth> (also written separately), a concessive conditional particle, = <foreign lang="greek">kai\ ei)</foreign>, more emphatic than etsi, <sense id="n16299.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">even if</hi>, <hi rend="ital">although</hi>, <hi rend="ital">albeit.</hi> </sense><sense id="n16299.1" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">indic.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiamsi alterum tantum perdundum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:3:4:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 3, 4, 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiamsi dudum fuerat ambiguum hoc mihi: Nunc non est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:4:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 4, 4, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ista veritas etiamsi jucunda non est, mihi tamen grata est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:3:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 3, 24 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so opp. tamen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:84:290" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 84, 290</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:10:13" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 10, 13</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">opp. certe,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 17 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,041:2:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Opt. Gen. 2, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:15:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 15, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">eundem igitur esse creditote, etiamsi nullum videbitis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:de Sen. 22:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Sen. 22, 79</bibl></cit> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n16299.2" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiamsi vetet, Edim, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae etiamsi essent, quae nulla sunt, pellere se ipsa fortasse possent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:39:110" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 39, 110</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:7:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 1, 7, 18</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 10, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:43:154" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 43, 154</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod, etiamsi nobilitatum non sit, tamen honestum est, quodque vere dicimus, etiamsi a nullo laudetur, natura esse laudabile,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:8:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 8, 21</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:27:100" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 27, 100</bibl> et saep.; <cit><quote lang="la">opp. certe,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Cons. ad Helv. 1:1" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Cons. ad Helv. 1, 1</bibl></cit>; Treb. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:12:16:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 12, 16, 11</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">opp. nihilominus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:48:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 48, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:23:3:19" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 23, 3, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:47:2:63" default="NO">47, 2, 63</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n16299.3" n="(g)" level="5"> Without a verb: <cit><quote lang="la">hunc librum etiamsi minus nostra commendatione, tuo tamen nomine divulgari necesse sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:chapter=31" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 31 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:12:5" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 12, 5</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">opp. at,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 3, 8</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quae mihi omnia etiamsi non prius, attamen clarius fulsisse in Scipione Aemiliano videntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 27, 28, § 100</bibl></cit> et saep. Vid. Hand, Turs. II. pp. 588-596.</sense></entryFree>
etiamtum: <entryFree id="n16300" type="main" key="e^ti^amtum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĕtĭam-tum</orth> <itype>and</itype> (more rarely) <orth extent="full" lang="la">ĕtĭam-tunc</orth>, <sense id="n16300.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">conj.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">even then</hi>, <hi rend="ital">till that time</hi>, <hi rend="ital">till then</hi>, <hi rend="ital">still.</hi> </sense><sense id="n16300.1" n="I" level="1"> With <hi rend="ital">imperf. tense</hi> (so usually): omnes etiamtum retinebant illum Pericli sucum; <cit><quote lang="la">sed erant paulo uberiore filo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 22 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etiamtum vita hominum sine cupiditate agitabatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 2, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 63:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> J. 63, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">manebant etiamtum vestigia monentis libertatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nam etiamtum Agricola Britanniam obtinebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 39</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:42" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 42</bibl>; so with cum, <hi rend="ital">while ... still</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum isti etiamtum de Sthenio in integro tota res esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 39 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">cum etiamtum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 5, 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 51:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 51, 2</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n16300.2" n="B" level="2"> The <hi rend="ital">imperf.</hi> is sometimes represented by, </sense><sense id="n16300.3" n="1" level="3"> A <hi rend="ital">part.</hi> or <pos>adj.</pos>: <cit><quote lang="la">trepida etiamtum civitate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 40:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 40, 4</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 21:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 21, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 49</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quam defunctam praetextatus etiamtunc pro rostris laudavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:10" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum viderem, ne vobis quidem omnibus re etiamtum probata, si, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 2, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n16300.4" n="2" level="3"> By the <hi rend="ital">praes. histor.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">narrat, ut virgo ab se integra etiamtum siet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:1:2:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 1, 2, 70</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n16300.5" n="3" level="3"> By the <hi rend="ital">pluperf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque is deductus etiamtum ad eam (erat),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:5:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 3, 5, 22</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n16300.6" n="II" level="1"> With other tenses (very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">illi qui etiamtum, cum misereri mei debent, non desinunt invidere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:5:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 4, 5, 1</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 3, p. 134, 1</bibl>. Vid. Hand, Turs. II. pp. 596-600.</sense></entryFree>
etruria: <entryFree id="n16301" type="main" key="E_^tru_ri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ē^trūrĭa</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Het-</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n16301.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a country of central Italy</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:4:2" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 4, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 8, § 50</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:41:92" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 41, 92</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 2, 3 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=32" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 32</bibl> Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:35:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 35, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:494" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 494</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">12, 232</bibl> et saep.—Deriv., </sense><sense id="n16301.1" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ē^truscus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of Etruria</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Etruscan</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">litus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:7:19" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 7, 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 2, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:Sec. 38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. Sec. 38</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:16:40" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Epod. 16, 40</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:29:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. 3, 29, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">juga,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:480" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 480</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">duces,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 11, 598</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">manus Porsenae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:16:4" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 16, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">disciplina,</quote> <trans><tr>the Etruscan religion</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:6:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 6, 6, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:199" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 83, 85, § 199</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:37" default="NO" valid="yes">10, 15, 17, § 37</bibl>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">haruspices,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:4:5:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 4, 5, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">litterae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">coronae,</quote> <trans><tr>made of gold and precious stones</tr>, <tr>and worn by those who triumphed</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 3, 4, § 6</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sing.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 1, 4, § 11</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> de Coron. 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aurum,</quote> <trans><tr>a golden amulet worn by Roman boys of noble birth</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:5:164" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 5, 164</bibl></cit> et saep.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Etrusci</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the Etruscans</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:42" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 34</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 7</bibl> et saepiss.</sense></entryFree>
etsi: <entryFree id="n16302" type="main" key="etsi"><orth extent="full" lang="la">et-si</orth>, <sense id="n16302.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">conj.</hi> [et, II. H.], like etiamsi, a concessive conditional particle, <hi rend="ital">though</hi>, <hi rend="ital">although</hi>, <hi rend="ital">albeit.</hi> </sense><sense id="n16302.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop. </sense><sense id="n16302.2" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">indic.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">gaudeo, etsi nihil scio, quod gaudeam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:2:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 4, 2, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etsi scio ego, Philumena, meum jus esse ... ego tamen, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:2:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 2, 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etsi abest maturitas aetatis, jam tamen personare aures ejus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:18:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 6, 18, 3</bibl></cit>: ergo, etsi conferre manum pudor iraque monstrat, Obiciunt portas<cb n="EUBO" />  tamen, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 44</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">vapulo hercle ego invitus tamen, Etsi malum merui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:5:3:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 5, 3, 16</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:5:2:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 5, 2, 63</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">so often followed by certe, saltem, verumtamen, etc.: etsi aliqua culpa tenemur, a scelere certe liberati sumus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,032:5:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Marcell. 5, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:3:60 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 2, 3, 60 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n16302.3" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">etsi taceas, palam id quidem est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:3:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 3, 2, 7</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:3:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 4, 3, 41</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">etsi cupidissime expetitum a me sit, tamen, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etsi nihil aliud Sullae nisi consulatum abstulissetis, tamen eo vos contentos esse oportebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:32:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 32, 90</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 8 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n16302.4" n="(g)" level="5"> Ellipt., without a verb: <cit><quote lang="la">ei, etsi nequaquam parem illius ingenio, ut meritam gratiam referamus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:4:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 4, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">superbiae crudelitatique etsi seras, non leves tamen venire poenas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 56</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 38, 41</bibl> (twice): <cit><quote lang="la">etsi non iniquum certe triste senatus consultum factum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 26, 6, 2</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:12" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 12</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Or. 19</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n16302.5" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, sometimes like quamquam, to restrict or correct a preceding proposition, <hi rend="ital">although</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and yet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">kai/per, kai/toi</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">vale atque salve: etsi aliter ut dicam meres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:5:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 3, 5, 86</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">utram (conditionem) malis vide: etsi hoc consilium rectum esse scio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 85</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">habet enim res deliberationem: etsi ex parte magna tibi assentior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 3, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 13, 41</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">do, do poenas temeritatis meae. Etsi quae fuit illa temeritas?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 10, 2</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 16, 7, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">lectis tuis litteris admiratus equidem sum, te, etc.: etsi, quamvis non fueris suasor et impulsor profectionis meae, approbator certe fuisti,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit> § 2; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quamquam, etsi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:19:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 19, 4</bibl></cit>. Vid. Hand, Turs. II. pp. 600-609.</sense></entryFree>
etymologia: <entryFree id="n16303" type="greek" key="e^ty^mo^lo^gi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĕtymŏlŏgĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">e)tumologi/a</foreign>, <sense id="n16303.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">etymology</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 1, 8, 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:6:1" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 6, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:28" default="NO">28</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:3:25" default="NO">7, 3, 25</bibl> et saep. (<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:8:35" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 8, 35</bibl>, written as Greek, and transl. by veriloquium).</sense></entryFree>
etymologice: <entryFree id="n16304" type="greek" key="e^ty^mo^lo^gi^ce"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĕtymŏlŏgĭce</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">e)tumologikh/</foreign>, <sense id="n16304.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">etymology</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=4" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 4</bibl> Müll. (<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:7:section=109" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 7, § 109</bibl>, written as Greek).</sense></entryFree>
etymologicus: <entryFree id="n16305" type="main" key="e^ty^mo^lo^gi^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĕtymŏlŏgĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">e)tumologiko/s</foreign>, <sense id="n16305.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">etymological</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:18:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 18, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
etymologos: <entryFree id="n16306" type="greek" key="e^ty^mo^lo^gos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĕtymŏlŏgos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">e)tumolo/gos</foreign>, <sense id="n16306.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an etymologist</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=39" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 39</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
etymon: <entryFree id="n16307" type="greek" key="e^ty^mon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĕtymon</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">e)/tumon</foreign>, <sense id="n16307.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the origin of a word</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">etymon habere,</quote> <trans><tr>to be derived</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:48:2" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 48, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">etyma (with origines),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:18:4:11 al" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 18, 4, 11 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
eu: <entryFree id="n16308" type="greek" key="eu"><orth extent="full" lang="la">eu</orth>, <pos>interj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">eu)=</foreign>, <sense id="n16308.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">well! well done! bravo!</hi> an exclamation of joy or approbation, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:4:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 1, 4, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 3, 1, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 4, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:2:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 1, 2, 74</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:328" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 328</bibl>.—Esp.: <cit><quote lang="la">Eu Hercle!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:1:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 5, 1, 31</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:5:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 3, 5, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:1:58 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 3, 1, 58 al.</bibl> Cf. Hand, Turs. II. p. 609 sq.; and see euge.</sense></entryFree>
euadne: <entryFree id="n16309" type="main" key="Euadne"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Euadne</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Euhadne</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Evadne</orth>), <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*eu)a/dnh</foreign>, <sense id="n16309.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">wife of Capaneus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">one of the</hi> "<hi rend="ital">Seven before Thebes;</hi>" <hi rend="ital">when her husband's body was burned</hi>, <hi rend="ital">she threw herself on the pile</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:13:24" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 13, 24</bibl> (4, 12, 24 M.); 1, 15, 21; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:447" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 447</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:4:3:64" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 4, 3, 64</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:4:75" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 4, 75</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 243" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 243</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n16309.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A nymph</hi>, <hi rend="ital">daughter of Asopus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:2:21:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 2, 21, 52</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
euan: <entryFree id="n16310" type="main" key="Euan"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Euan</orth>, v. Euhan.</entryFree>
euander: <entryFree id="n16311" type="main" key="Euander"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Euander</orth> (Gr. <case>nom.</case> <orth extent="full" lang="la">-drus</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:100:185 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 100, 185 al.</bibl>; <case>voc.</case> -dre, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 11, 55</bibl>. Less correctly, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Evander</orth>), <itype>dri</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*eu)/andros</foreign>. <sense id="n16311.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Son of Carmenta</hi> (v. Carmentis), <hi rend="ital">born at Pallantium</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in Arcadia; he emigrated to Italy sixty years before the Trojan war</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and there founded the city Pallanteum</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:471" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 471</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">497, 583</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 279</bibl>; 4, 65; 5, 91; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 52</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">119</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">9, 9</bibl>; 10, 515; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:3:91" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 3, 91</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Euandrĭ-us</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Evandrian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ensis,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>of Pallas</tr>, <tr>the son of Evander</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:394" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 394</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">regna,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Roman</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:7:18" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 7, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">collis,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the Palatine</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:4:1:7" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 4, 1, 7</bibl></cit>; also, <cit><quote lang="la">mons,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> VI. Cons. Honor. 11</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n16311.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A Greek artist in metals</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brought from Alexandria to Rome by M. Antony</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:3:91" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 3, 91</bibl> Schol.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 5, 4, § 32</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n16311.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An Academic philosopher</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 6, 16</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
euax: <entryFree id="n16312" type="main" key="euax"><orth extent="full" lang="la">euax</orth>, <pos>interj.</pos> <etym>only Plautine</etym>, expressive of delight at some tidings or event, <sense id="n16312.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">hail! joy! good!</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 2, 3, 13</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 4, 72</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> 4, 4, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
euboea: <entryFree id="n16313" type="main" key="Euboea"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Euboea</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*eu)/boia</foreign>, <sense id="n16313.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an island in the Aegean Sea</hi>, <hi rend="ital">separated from Boeotia by Euripus</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Negroponte</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:7:9" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 7, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 21, § 63</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:660 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 660 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n16313.1" n="II" level="1"> <cb n="EUGE" /> Derivv. </sense><sense id="n16313.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Eubŏĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Euboean</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">litus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:26:38" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 26, 38</bibl></cit> (3, 22, 18 M.); cf. <cit><quote lang="la">cautes,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the promontory Caphareus</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:260" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 260</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sinus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4</bibl></cit> (5), 1, 114: <cit><quote lang="la">undae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:218" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 218</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Anthedon,</quote> <trans><tr>in Boeotia</tr>, <tr>opposite Euboea</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 7, 232</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">13, 905</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">cultor aquarum,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Glaucus</tr>, <tr>from Anthedon</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:14:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 14, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbs,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Cumae</tr>, <tr>as a colony of Euboean Chalcidians</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:14:155" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 14, 155</bibl></cit>;
